Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>COlin,
>
>I was also curious, what experiments are those really complicated-
>looking networks from?
>  
>

The clue is in the file names :)

dpnv_antiwiggle_0_606,03_045909_085921.png
This is double pole, no velocity with anti-wiggle fitness scoring.

and the really complex one:
preycap_64from64.png

This is prey capture with the 64 determinstic tests. This network is 
perfect on all 64 tests but obviously contains a LOT of redundant 
neurons/connections. In fact it's a small wonder such a complex network 
was able to make any gains towards the end of the search due to the 
large size of the search space.

I would say that these large networks are really the result of some very 
long searches(like about 24 hours) where the add neuron/connections 
rates where too high, but then even with low mutation rates I would 
expect some accumulation of neurons during a long search that has gone 
through periods of stagnation. This is why I want to try using a phased 
search whereby we alternate between adding neurons/connections and 
trimming them back - I think it should improve very long duration searches.

Colin.
